fr.sorbonne_u.alasca.physical_data

Class ComposedSignalData

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sorbonne_u.alasca.physical_data.TimedEntity
      • fr.sorbonne_u.alasca.physical_data.AbstractSignalData
        • fr.sorbonne_u.alasca.physical_data.ComposedSignalData
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    TimingI, java.io.Serializable

    public class ComposedSignalData
extends AbstractSignalData
    The class ComposedSignalData implements a composed signal data, with its own time stamping information, and combining several single or composed signal data having their own time stamping information.

    Description

    Implementation Invariants

     invariant       data != null && data.length > 1 && Stream.of(data).allMatch(sd -> sd != null)

    Invariants

     invariant       true        // no more invariant

    Created on : 2025-09-17

    Author:
    Jacques Malenfant
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • ComposedSignalData

        public ComposedSignalData(AbstractSignalData[] data)
        create a composed signal data with the given array of signal data as content, the current time as time stamp, the current host as time stamper and its hardware clock giving the time reference.

        Description

        Note that the array data is not copied but kept as is in the resulting composed signal data, hence introducing sharing between the calling context and the newly created composed signal data.

        Contract

         pre     data != null && data.length > 1 && Stream.of(data).allMatch(sd -> sd != null)
 post    getTimestamp().equals(Instant.ofEpochMilli(System.currentTimeMillis())
 post    getTimeReference().equals(getStandardTimestamper())
        Parameters:
        data - array of signal data that will be the content of the new composed signal data.

        Parameters:

      • ComposedSignalData

        public ComposedSignalData(AbstractSignalData[] data,
                          java.time.Instant timestamp,
                          java.lang.String timestamper)
        create a composed signal data with the given array of signal data as content, the given time stamp, time stamper identity and the current host hardware clock giving the time reference.

        Contract

         pre     data != null && data.length > 1 && Stream.of(data).allMatch(sd -> sd != null)
 pre     timestamp != null
 pre     timestamper != null && !timestamper.isEmpty()
 post    getTimestamp().equals(timestamp)
 post    getTimeReference().equals(getTimestamper())
        Parameters:
        data - array of signal data that will be the content of the new composed signal data.
        timestamp - time stamp as a Java Instant object.
        timestamper - identity of the time stamping host e.g., its IP address.

        public ComposedSignalData(AbstractSignalData[] data,
                          fr.sorbonne_u.utils.aclocks.AcceleratedClock ac)
        create a composed signal data with the given array of signal data as content, the current time as time stamp, the current host as time stamper and the given accelerated clock giving the time reference.

 post    getTimestamp().equals(ac.currentInstant())
 post    getTimeReference().equals(((Supplier<String>) () -> { try { return ac.getTimeReferenceIdentity(); } catch (UnknownHostException e) { return UNKNOWN_TIMESTAMPER; }}).get())
        Parameters:

      • collectReferenceEpochTimesInNanos

        protected void collectReferenceEpochTimesInNanos(java.util.Set<java.lang.Long> s)
        Description copied from class: TimedEntity
        collect reference Unix Epoch times in nanoseconds of the time stampers of timed entity; for a TimedEntity, there is only one time stamper.

        Description

        The objective of this method is to compare the time stampers among a set of timed entities to ensure that there is not a so large deviation among them that their time stamps become incomparable. The time stamper of a TimedEntity can be either an accelerated clock or the hardware clock of the host on which it has been created. For the moment, we consider that the hardware clocks of the computers used in an application are correctly synchronised, so the method puts in the set s the current Unix Epoch time in nanoseconds on the current host so that as the collection is assumed to be fast, this will result as a coherent set of time stampers if only hardware clocks have been used to time stamp all of the timed entities.

        If the time stamper is an accelerated clock, the method puts in s its start time in Unix Epoch time in nanoseconds. Hence, if all of the collected times come from accelerated clocks, differences in their start times can be large and therefore subject to deviations that must be detected. As we assume that in applications, their differences should be as small as possible. If there is a mix between accelerated clocks and hardware clocks used to time stamp the timed entities, the differences between their start times of accelerated clocks and the current times of hardware clocks should be large enough to be detected as a too large deviation, so an incoherent set of time stampers.

        Contract

         pre     s != null
 post    true        // no postcondition.
        Overrides:
        collectReferenceEpochTimesInNanos in class TimedEntity
        Parameters:
        s - the set to which must be added the start time in Unix Epoch time in nanoseconds according to the accelerated clock of this timed entity.
        See Also:
        TimedEntity.collectReferenceEpochTimesInNanos(java.util.Set)
